div.head:
Embleme 42. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Nature, Reason, Experience, and reading must be the guide, staffestaff,
Spectacles, and Lamp to him that is employdemployed in Chymicall affairs.

lg.l: Pursuing art, let Nature be your guide,
Tracing her steps your feet will not back=slide:
Let reason be your staffe, experience add
Strength to your sight, discerning good from bad:
In darkenesse reading will as light direct,

div.head: Discourse 42.
div.ab:
The chances, which may happen to travellerstravelers, are innumerable, es
pecially if they take a journey on foot by night through slippery-
and dangerous places; to which four things are requisite as cheife
ly necessary, not to speake of the virtuallsvirtuals provided, and a strong-
body: In the first place, a companion or guide not ignorant of the
wayes, through which hee must passe: For if one ignorant man-
guide another, the same thing happens to them as to blind men, if
they doe not both fall headlong into a dittchditch, yet into errours and-
mistakes: Secondly, a Staffe, by which the slipperinesseslipperiness and perill
of the way, lest it be detrimentalldetrimental to a man, may be avoyded: Third
ly, sound eyes, for such journeys are most dangerous to the blind or
dimmedim sighted: Fourthly, a lamp or lighted torch, that the diversitysdiversities
and differences of the wayes may be discerned. After the same-
manner if a man expose himselfe to a most difficult journey in
pursuit of the Philosophicke medicine, hee will, besides charge-
and strength of body, desire four things exactly parallellparallel and cor
respondent to those aforesayd, to witt, Nature, Reason, experience,
and reading: whereof if any one be wanting, the rest will doe-
little or noe good at all: For by these, as by four wheeleswheels, the Philo
sophicke chariot moves, to which one of the wheeles cannot be-
wanting, if it be left, it avayls nothing. Nature præsupposethpresupposes natu
rall bodyes and Spirits, as subjects first ministredministered by nature, upon
which art must afterwards act, præparing, purifying, and fitting it,
that thereof may be made that, which art promisethpromises for the end:
Soe a Potter takes water and earth, a Glasse=maker ashes and-
Sand, a Smith iron, copper, tinne, lead, Silver or gold, a Tanner
raw hides, and soe other men other things: Such respect allso-
hath the operator of Chymistry to his materiallsmaterials: Their materi
allsmaterials are to them very well knowne even the first day, hee, when
hee begins, continues for the most part ignorant of his for many
years, I will not say, during his whole life. Nature doth indeed-
point at the matters, but there are many things, which obscure the-
impression of nature, that it cannot be knowne. The first intention-
therefore is, seriously to contemplate how nature proceeds in her ope
rations to the end that the naturall subjects of Chymistry may-
without defect or superfluity be had: Wherefore Nature must be-
the guide and companion of soe great a journey, whose footsteps-
must be traced. Secondly, reason must be as a staffe to keep the-
steps and feet steady and firme, that they may not slip or waver,
For without the exercise of reason a man will be apt to fall-

into errours, and therefore say the Philosophers; Whatsoever you hear,
consult with reason, whether it can be soe, or noe: For noe man is
forced to beleive or performe things impossible, except hee be of-
weakeweak memory, dull genius, and foolish imagination to impose upon
himselfe accepting things false for true, and rejecting true for false:
They say allso that they care not for words, whatsoever may be-
spoken, but onely for things, what may be understood; And that
words are for things, and not things for words: As for example, Suppose
a man say that glasse is made malleable by the Philosophicall-
tincture; Why Shall not I beleive it, if provided reason dictates it?-
Thirdly, Experience will be as Spectacles, by which things may be-
seen at a distance; These are optickeoptic instruments, invented and made
by art, to helpe and amend the weaknesse of mens eyes. Much like to
these are experiments about the minerall matter of every kind tryed,
seen or truely heard, which the more they are in memory, the more
will a man of reason draw from thence, and compare them among-
and with other things, that hee may perceive, what is true, what not-
Fourthly, Reading dos as it were kindle a clear lamp in the understan
ding, without which there will be every where darkenesse and thicke
clouds. But the reading of good authors ought to be often repeated,-
otherwise it will not be at all effectuall. Hereupon Bacasser in Turba
sayth: Hee therefore, that is of an even temper, and exercisethexercises pati
ence without regrettregret, will attaine to this art as by a direct line, but
hee, that thinks himselfe able sooner to reap benefit from our books,
is deceived, and it had been better not to have lookdlooked therein, than-
ever to have touchdtouched them: And soe on. . . . . .
